Great video, but i dont like the way the coordinate system is labled. At 7:42 we see arrows that indicate what direction on the axis would be positive on both ends of the axis. Then, looking at 8:09 If we choose  the x axis to point towards the upper right corner, then in our fs would be positive and Fgx would be negative. So at 9:15 the equation for net force would have to be F net= fs,max-mg sin theta = -26,29 N since in this coordinate system the box moving downward is a movement in negative x direction. By the logic in the video with the x axis orientation the box would move up the ramp rather then down, since the resulting force is in positive x direction, i e up the ramp. Watch your coordinate system orientations. Though what can be seen in the video is correct, most likely you would get points deducted for incorrect labelling.

yes, remember that it changes its strength to match up the applied force, as long as it is less than or equal to the max static friction. once the applied force (from, I dunno, your hands or something) passes that amount, it will be no longer in equilibrium.

The magnitude of normal force changes in response to the exerted force. Since max force of static fricition= coefficient of static friction * normal force, the static friction changes and thus is in equilibrium when not in motion

yes it's still in equilibrium, because static friction changes according to the applied, if the maximum static friction is 5N and you apply 3N, then the static friction opposing your applied force is also 3N, the maximum is 5N , that doesn't mean it's always 5N it changes to match the applied force so long as the applied force is 5N and below.

Sorry but it would be a lot clearer if anyone said what the value of coefficient of static friction is.. I can google it up but it would be a lot clearer if someone explained it clearly to me

it is how much friction surfaces have. it varies by the materials involved and in what combination, like a tire on asphalt vs tire on ice.  my teacher also likes to remind us it doesn't have "definite" constants either (you cant exactly calculate it by math alone).  it is determined by a scientist rubbing two materials together and measuring how much force before it begins to move. then they divide the force at which it starts moving (the maximum force the static friction can oppose) by the normal force to get μ

+Mikael Jensen Nah, the gravitational force of the bookcase on the ground is irrelevant. A force pair are two forces that are opposing each other, as described by newton's 3rd law. The bookcase's force down from gravity is equal and opposite the normal force up from the ground, thus creating a force pair.

Nope. Two forces can be opposite and equal without forming a N3 pair. Newton's third law states that if on object exerts a force on another object, the second object will exert an opposite and equal force on the first object. The gravitational force on the ground by the bookcase is exactly equal and opposite that of the ground on the bookcase. This is a N3 pair. However the normalforce can be non-equal and non-opposite that of the gravitational force. Simply think of a ball rolling on a slope. The normal force is there but neither equal of opposite that of the gravitational force. Thus these do not constitute a N3 pair.

3:15: The normal force is NOT the reaction force of the weight force.  The weight force is the force with which the earth pulls on the bookcase, and its reaction force is the bookcase pulling on the earth.  No two parts of an action/reaction pair can be drawn on the same free body diagram, since they act on different objects.  The value of the normal force on a flat surface (as in the bookcase example) should be calculated the same way you calculated it in the slope example--using equilibrium.

That statement at around 3:15 is a bit disturbing: "The force of the bookcase on the floor is just its weight, mg." This might be partially true: the reaction force that the floor experiences turns out to be equal and opposite to the normal force of the floor on the bookcase. It follows that this reaction force (which is ANOTHER NORMAL FORCE) from the bookcase on the floor is equal in magnitude to the weight of the bookcase.  However, by stating that "The force of the bookcase on the floor is just its weight," you're almost implying that the the newton's 3rd law reaction force to the normal force on the bookcase... is a gravitational force (weight) on the very same object, which is nonsense.   See, while it may seem like a minor error here, I feel like many students will get confused about how Newton's third law actually work. They'll think that the weight being equal and opposite to the normal force of the bookcase is an example of the third law, which is a much more common misconception than you'd think.

+DJ Quazzy Evil   >Ok, so the box will slide down the ramp, but how fast will it move?  You can actually solve that using the equations of motion presented earlier.

+DJ Quazzy Evil Once you've decided that it will slide (by doing the check against maximum static friction as shown in the video), you know that it'll start moving, so you replace the static friction term with the kinetic friction term. That gives you a net force, which you then simply plug into F = m*a to figure out the acceleration, and then v = a*t to figure out the velocity (which increases over time t).

+DJ Quazzy Evil As for whether the bookcase tips over, you can do a free body diagram about the bottom right of the book case, and easily test whether the torque produced by pushing on the book case (which depends on how high up the bookcase you're pressing) is enough to overcome gravity and tip it over.

I had a big old debate on their last video about how physics work in space, and how its not the object youre acting on pushing you back, its your own force pushing you back.  Either this show is really crappy at explaining things or its just simply not an actual thing.  When an object is at rest against another object, its at equilibrium, it is not moving, all the forces are balanced, unless a gust of wind comes along and blows it away it will stay there. Gravity keeps it in place, and once its resting against another object it will stay there unless acted upon by an outside force.   The object a thing is resting on is not pushing back, if anything the thing is pushing against the object it rests against, proportional to the strength of gravity and its mass.  This applies stress to the object it is sitting on, effectively as if it had the added weight of the thing at rest, but its not pushing back against the thing with an "equal but opposite reaction" if it were truly "equal and opposite" then it wouldnt have any stress applied to it at all, and collisions would be inertialess.

+WeAreGRID "I had a big old debate on their last video about how physics work in space, and how its not the object youre acting on pushing you back, its your own force pushing you back."  I know you did.  You were wrong then, and you're wrong now.  " Gravity keeps it in place, and once its resting against another object it will stay there unless acted upon by an outside force. "  You are denying the validity of Newton's second law.  If the net force on an object is not zero, the object will accelerate,;it will not remain at rest. If there is one non-zero force acting on an object, and it is at rest, there must be another force.  In your example, the thing being rested against is supplying that missing force.  That's what the phrase "resting against" means.

Michael Sommers youre misunderstanding, if its at rest the net force is zero, its not accelerating anywhere, the only reason it doesnt go anywhere when its stuck to an object by gravity is because theres a SOLID OBJECT in the way!  if that object wasnt there, the forces still being enacted on it would take effect, but there isnt a physical mechanical way for a brick to exert force against another brick sitting atop it, they neither of them have any momentum, or mechanical power to move, or apply force, or anything, theyre both at rest, touching eachother.  Its not that Object B provides an opposite force to counter the force of gravity, its that there is nowhere to accelerate TO.  Gravity is an attraction, but if youre held in place you could be anywhere in the world, or any world, and still not move. you have no momentum if you have nowhere to move, you can be accelerated against all you like, but you wont move if youre stuck to a thing. they kind of explained it with friction, you cant move a massive bookshelf very easily because of friction, but thats not all there is going on, it just has so much mass, that the effective force of gravity is trying its hardest to accelerate it downwards, but it has nowhere to go, so it stays still. When you push it, it has to effectively be greater than the force of friction involved, and the effective weight of the object. On a frictionless surface, you can apply as much downwards force as you like, but its still free to move laterally, because nothing is stopping it.  its as if in the three dimensional plane, the Z axis ended at 0, you can move left and right, but not downwards, theres just no more down you can get. youll never develop inertia if there is nowhere to go.  So, the downwards force applies stress in the real world, you can crack the floor in the real world, or smash the bookcase beneath a few tons of weight, but its still not going anywhere. There is nowhere to go.  The whole concept of an opposite force countering the downwards force is ludicrous, the floor cant apply force, it is sitting still. An object at rest will stay at rest. You can apply as much downwards acceleration as you like, as much force, as you like, but theres nowhere to GO so it isnt going to change, youll just eventually break the floor, and then the force that was already being enacted upon it will take effect, it will fall to the next floor, maybe its inertia will be great enough to break that floor, and so on, but without somewhere to go, acceleration is meaningless.
